Experimental investigation on the correlation between nano-fluid characteristics and thermal properties of Al2O3 nano-particles dispersed in ethylene glycol–water mixture

Article history: Received 8 June 2015 Received in revised form 10 November 2015 Accepted 11 November 2015
Keywords: Nano-fluids Al2O3 nano-particle Ethylene glycol–water mixture Zeta potential Thermal properties
This paper presents a multi-parameter investigation of Al2O3 nano-particles dispersed in distilled water, ethylene glycol and ethylene glycol–distilled water mixture (50/50 vol.%). The nano-fluid samples were prepared with ultrasonic processing with particle concentration up to 9 wt.%. Samples were characterized by transmission electron microscope imaging, particle surface charge (zeta potential), particle aggregate size, light absorbance and pH. The thermal conductivity and viscosity of the nano-fluid samples were measured. 10.9% enhancement in thermal conductivity was observed in ethylene glycol–distilled water mixture based nano-fluid with 5 wt.% Al2O3 nano-particle loading. The results show multipleperspective correlations between nano-fluid characteristics and thermal properties. The findings are summarized as follows. Combined effect of base fluid viscosity and particle surface charge determines the degree of nano-particle aggregation. Higher enhancement in thermal conductivity is observed with moderate particle aggregation, while either light or heavy aggregation lowers the enhancement. The ethylene glycol–water mixture based nano-fluids show overall higher thermal conductivity enhancement than the distilled water and ethylene glycol based nano-fluids. The degradation of nano-fluid thermal conductivity enhancement over time is found to be related to the gravity-driven particle sedimentation. Nano-fluids containing larger particle aggregates show higher viscosity augmentation. However, the extent of viscosity augmentation is not proportional to the extent of particle aggregation.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The need for improved efficiency of automotive thermal management systems is driven by the trend that the automotive powertrain system operates at higher power output with additional heat sources such as intercooler, oil cooler, and exhaust gas recirculation cooler in a limited engine room space. One of the potential solutions is to enhance the thermal performance of the heat transfer fluid. Inspired by the effective thermal conductivity study by Maxwell [1], nanotechnology-based advanced cooling fluids have been studied for thermal performance improvement of the conventional fluids [2–7]. Nano-fluids are made by dispersing nanometersized particles into conventional heat transfer fluids.
Al2O3 is one of the most suitable nano-particle materials that can be used in automotive applications for several reasons. Lower cost of the Al2O3 is preferable for mass production [8]. Al2O3 nanoparticle is categorized as a ceramic nano-particle [9] which, unlike many metallic nano-particles, is not susceptible to surface oxidation and is much easier to incorporate into a fluid [10]. Although the thermal conductivity of Al2O3 is not significantly high among the other metal oxide materials such as CuO and ZnO, its thermal conductivity is higher than those of the conventional heat transfer fluids by two orders of magnitude [11].
Extensive research has been conducted on the Al2O3 nanoparticle dispersed in water or ethylene glycol (EG) [12–16]. However, there are limited studies on the EG–water mixture based Al2O3 nano-fluids. Vajjha et al. [17] investigated the thermal conductivity of EG–water mixture (60/40 wt.%) based Al2O3 nanofluids over the temperature range of 17–90 C at various particle volume fractions up to 10%. Their result shows that the thermal conductivity of the nano-fluid over the base fluid increases with the increase in particle concentration and temperature. It was also
found that thermal conductivity decreased with increased particle diameter. Beck et al. [18] measured the thermal conductivity of 50/50 wt.% EG/water based Al2O3 nano-fluid over an extended temperature range up to 420 K. The volume fraction tested was from 0.5 to 4%. Two particle sizes, 10 and 50 nm, were tested in their study. They claimed that the thermal conductivitytemperature behavior of the nano-fluid followed closely the behavior of the base fluid. The thermal conductivity enhancement of the 10 nm particle was smaller than that of the 50 nm particle, which is different from the finding by Vajjha et al. [17]. LotfizadehDehkordi et al. [19] studied the viscosity of 0.01–1 vol.% Al2O3 nanoparticle dispersed in 60/40 wt.% EG/water with the addition of dispersant over the temperature range of 25–40 C. The increase in the viscosity shows a nonlinear relationship with the particle loading. The viscosity was also found to be highly temperature dependent. Yiamsawas et al. [20] investigated the viscosity of Al2O3 nano-particle suspended in the mixture of EG/water (20/80 wt.%). The experiments were conducted at the volume fractions from 0% to 4% and the temperature range of 15–60 C. The results indicate that the nano-fluid viscosity increases when particle loading increases and temperature decreases. The differences in the viscosities of nano-fluids at various particle loadings decrease with the increase in temperature. In the study done by Syam Sundar et al. [21], Al2O3 nano-particles were dispersed in different EG/ water mixtures (20/80 wt.%, 40/60 wt.% and 60/40 wt.%). The thermal conductivity and viscosity were measured over the temperature range of 20–60 C and the particle volume concentration range of 0.3% to 1.5%. They found that the enhancements of the thermal conductivity and the viscosity depended not only on the particle concentration and temperature but also on base fluid properties.
These experiments mainly focused on the nano-fluid property studies. Some of them showed the correlation between nanofluid characteristics and properties. However, the nano-fluid characteristic parameters studied in previous works were limited, they did not provide a systematic view on the mechanism behind the nano-fluid properties. Nano-fluids are multivariable systems, with each thermo-physical property depending on several parameters including nano-particle material, concentration, size and shape, properties of the base fluid, presence of additives, surfactants, electrolyte strength, and pH [22]. Therefore, a multiple-parameter approach is used to investigate the behavior of the Al2O3 based nano-fluids in this study. The nano-particles are dispersed in 50/50 vol.% EG/distilled water (DW) mixture and each of the base fluids. Two-step process (method) is used for the nano-fluid sample preparation. Nano-fluid sample is characterized by transmission electron microscope (TEM) imaging, particle surface charge, particle sizing, light absorbance and pH. Nano-fluid thermal properties are investigated by measuring the thermal conductivity and viscosity. Nano-particle sedimentation within the nano-fluid is examined. The results are expected to offer multi-perspective correlations between the nano-fluid characterization and performance.

sections.heading: 2.1. Nano-fluid material
sections.text:
Al2O3 nano-particle used in this study was purchased from Nanophase Technologies Corp. (Romeoville, IL, USA). The particles are claimed to be spherical with the mean particle size of 40 nm by the manufacturer. However, the mean particle size from the TEM image was found to be 29.7 nm with a ±15.0 nm standard deviation based on the number-weighted particle size analysis. The TEM image is shown in Fig. 1 and the particle size distribution is
shown in Fig. 2. DW and pure EG were used as base fluids. 50/50 vol.% EG/DW mixture was made by mixing the DW and the pure EG.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nano-fluid characterization
sections.text: Particle surface charge (zeta potential) was measured by a particle analyzer (Beckman Coulter, Inc., Model Delsa Nano C), which is based on the electrophoretic light scattering technique. The particle zeta potential is an indicator of the strength of the repulsive force between the particles. The sufficient repulsive force can counteract the natural attractive force between the particles to prevent particles from aggregation. Otherwise, particles tend to aggregate. The zeta potentials of 0.1 g Al2O3 nano-particles in 10 mL of 3 base fluids (DW, EG and 50/50 EG/DW) were measured. Each sample was prepared by mixing the nano-powder with the base fluid for 1 min using a vortex mixer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Inc.). The dispersed particle aggregate size was measured by a particle analyzer (Beckman Coulter, Inc., Model Delsa Nano C) based on the dynamic light scattering technique. According to the Beer’s law [23], the particle concentration in the nano-fluid directly affects the light absorbance of the nano-fluid. Therefore, an ultraviolet–visible spectrometer (Ocean Optics, Inc., Model USB4000) was used to determine the supernatant particle concentration variation with the particle sedimentation. In order to determine the viability of nano-fluid for real-world applications without causing any corrosion issues, the pH level of nano-fluids was measured using a pH meter (Mettler Toledo, Model S220) with a 0.001 pH resolution.

sections.heading: 2.3. Nano-fluid property measurement
sections.text:
The thermal conductivity of the nano-fluid was measured using a thermal property analyzer device (Decagon Devices, Inc., Model KD2 Pro) which is based on the transient line heat source method. The accuracy of the sensor is ±5% over the thermal conductivity range of 0.2–2 W/m K and the temperature span of 0 to 60 C. The device can be set up in auto mode to continuously log measurements at 15 min increment. The thermal conductivity was measured at 25 C in a temperature controlled water bath. Data logging was started 15 min after the nano-fluids were prepared and installed in the water bath to allow the temperatures of nano-fluid sample and sensor to be equilibrated to the testing temperature. Four particle loadings (3, 5, 7 and 9 wt.%) were tested with different base fluids (DW, EG and 50/50 EG/DW). Base fluid volume was fixed to be 100 mL for each nano-fluid sample. All the particles and base fluids were weighed with an analytical balance (Mettler Toledo, Model AE200) with a 0.0001 g readability.
To prepare the sample, a magnetic stirrer (IKA, Model RCT basic) was used first to stir the sample for 5 min, right after weighed dry nano-powder being poured into the base fluid. Then, a 500 Watts horn-type ultra-sonicator (Qsonica LLC., Model Q500) was used for the main process to disperse the nano-powder into the base fluid. The ultra-sonicator was set to operate at 90% amplitude and in a pulse mode (10 s on and 10 s off). The duration of the ultra-sonication process was set at 60 min. Fig. 3 shows the variation of particle aggregate size and thermal conductivity enhancement of 5 wt.% Al2O3 in 50/50 EG/DW samples processed for different ultra-sonication durations. The thermal conductivity enhancement is defined as the percentage increase in the thermal conductivity of nano-fluid over the thermal conductivity of base fluid. It indicates that the particle aggregate size is at the minimum level and the thermal conductivity enhancement is at the maximum level with 60 min duration. However, due to the normal wear of the ultra-sonicator tip, prolonged ultra-sonication over 60 min usually contaminates the sample with a noticeable thin layer of tip debris precipitating at the bottom of the sample after the ultra-sonication process. To ensure the sample reproducibility, the ultra-sonictor tip condition was examined before the preparation and sample properties were tested at the end of the ultrasonication process.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of ultra-sonication duration
sections.text:
The effect of ultra-sonication duration on particle aggregate size variation of 5 wt.% Al2O3 dispersed in different base fluids is shown in Fig. 4. It indicates that the Al2O3 nano-particles are highly aggregated after mixed with the base fluids. The initial particle aggregate size in EG, 50/50 EG/DW, and DW are 244067, 1512 and 326 nm, respectively. The first 15-min ultra-sonication shows the most dramatic aggregate-break-down effect on all the samples. The particle aggregate size is reduced by 50% in EG, 44% in 50/50 EG/DW and 54% in DW. The subsequent ultra-sonication breaks
down the aggregates less efficiently but continuously. Fig. 4 also shows the difference of overall particle aggregate size in different base fluids. The particle aggregates in EG is larger than those in 50/50 EG/DW and DW. The smallest aggregates are found in DW.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of base fluid
sections.text:
Table 1 shows the correlation between nano-particle aggregation, base fluid viscosity and nano-particle surface charge. The smallest Al2O3 nano-particle aggregate size is achieved with the DW case due to the combined effect of the lowest base fluid viscosity and the highest particle surface charge. The moderate viscosity of 50/50 EG/DW plays a dominant role on the moderate particle aggregation in 50/50 EG/DW, in spite of the fact that the absolute value of particle zeta potential in 50/50 EG/DW is 85% lower than that in DW. The highest aggregation in EG can also be attributed to the combined effect of base fluid viscosity and particle surface charge, in which case EG has the highest viscosity and the absolute value of zeta potential is lowest.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of nano-particle aggregation on nano-fluid thermal conductivity enhancement
sections.text: Fig. 5 shows the thermal conductivity enhancement of 5 wt.% Al2O3 nano-particle in the base fluids of EG, DW and 50/50 EG/ DW. It indicates that the highest enhancement (10.9%) in thermal conductivity is achieved with 50/50 EG/DW based nano-fluid, followed by 4.3% enhancement with DW and 4.2% with EG. Fig. 5 also shows the final particle aggregate size result from the previous section. It shows that the highest enhancement occurs in 50/50 EG/ DW with the moderate particle aggregation. While in cases of light aggregation in DW and heavy aggregation in EG, the thermal conductivity enhancements are lower. This aggregation–enhancement relation matches with the results of other studies [14,24] of the particle aggregation effect on the thermal conductivity enhancement. This shows that an optimized level of particle aggregation could lead to the maximum enhancement in thermal conductivity. Being away from the optimized level, either increased or decreased aggregation level would decrease the enhancement.

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of nano-particle concentration
sections.text:
Fig. 6 shows the result of thermal conductivity enhancement in different base fluids at different loadings, along with the experimental results from other investigators [25–27]. It shows that thermal conductivity enhancement increases as the particle loading increases regardless of the base fluid type. It also indicates that the enhancements with 50/50 EG/DW are overall higher than those with water and EG.
In EG based nano-fluid case, the result from this study shows slightly lower enhancement than that reported by Lee et al. [25]. In water based nano-fluid case, the result from this study lies in between the results claimed by Lee et al. [25], Das et al. [26] and Eastman et al. [27]. Since none of those investigators provided the particle aggregate sizes at a specific particle loading in their studies, the discrepancy in the thermal conductivity enhancement may be caused by the particle aggregate sizes that can be signifi-
cantly varied depending on can be explained by the sample preparation methods.

sections.heading: 3.5. Viscosity augmentation of nano-fluids
sections.text:
Fig. 7 shows the result of nano-fluid viscosity augmentation as a function of the particle loading from the three base fluids. It shows that EG based nano-fluid has the highest viscosity augmentation followed by 50/50 EG/DW and DW at the same particle loading. As given in Table 1, the aggregate sizes in 50/50 EG/DW and EG were respectively 5.6 and 766 times larger than that in DW, while the percentages of viscosity augmentation in 50/50 EG/DW and EG were respectively 1.1 and 2.4 times greater. sections.heading: 3.6. Effect of nano-particle sedimentation
sections.text:
The particle sedimentation was investigated by measuring the light absorbance of the supernatant portion of the nano-fluid at every 5 min for the first 30 min and at every 15 min for another 90 min. This supernatant portion is also the location where the KD2 Pro sensor contacts with the nano-fluid sample for measuring thermal conductivity. Fig. 8 shows the light absorbance spectrum of 5 wt.% Al2O3 in 50/50 EG/DW measured at 0, 30 and 120 min. Fig. 9 shows the average light absorbance within a particular wavelength range (i.e. 600–800 nm) over time. Both show that the light absorbance of the supernatant portion decreases with time because less particles are suspended over time due to sedimentation.
In order to quantify the sedimentation effect on the thermal conductivity by using the light absorbance, an effective particle weight concentration concept is introduced in this study. At first,
the light absorbance of unsettled samples was measured in the range of the weight concentration from 1.5% to 5.0%. Then, the correlation between the light absorbance and the particle concentration was obtained. An example of the result for the case of 50/50 EG/DW is presented in Fig. 10. After that, the light absorbance in Fig. 9 is converted into the corresponding particle concentration, which is called effective particle concentration in this study, using the correlation shown in Fig. 10. This process has been repeated for the other base fluids and the outcomes are presented in Fig. 11. The effective concentration is an indirect measure of the concentration of the supernatant portion of the samples. The thermal conductivity enhancements are also plotted in Fig. 11. The thermal conductivity enhancement is declined proportionally to the percentages of the supernatant particle concentration loss. It indicates that the particle sedimentation causes the thermal conductivity decline over time. It was also noticed that the thermal conductivity enhancements of 50/50 EG/DW and DW based nano-fluids became negative after a certain period time. In case of EG based sample, the thermal conductivity enhancement decline is less influenced by the effective particle concentration in the first 30 min. The large
particle aggregation in EG based sample is considered to be the reason for this trend. Even when the effective particle concentration is relatively high, the enhancement in thermal conductivity is neutralized by the effect of particle heavy aggregation. During the rest period of 90 min, the thermal conductivity enhancement does not decline much as the effective particle concentration is
stabilized due to higher viscosity of EG. In summary, nanoparticle sedimentation is inevitable and disadvantageous for maintaining the thermal conductivity enhancement. The sedimentation is affected by the base fluid viscosity and the aggregation level. Keeping the nano-particles agitated in the dispersion would be a viable way to maintain its functionality. Further research to increase the stability of nano-particle after being dispersed in the base fluids would be very valuable.

sections.heading: 3.7. pH of base fluids and nano-fluids
sections.text: The pH values measured for base fluids and nano-fluids at different particle loadings are summarized in Table 2. The result shows that pH values of the base fluids are changed after nanoparticle dispersion. The largest pH change occurs in the case of EG followed by 50/50 EG/DW case. The least pH change is observed with DW case. However, there is no clear trend showing the pH variation with increasing particle loading. The change in pH to the base fluid is suspected to be caused by the chemical ingredient coming with the Al2O3 nano-particle. These impurities might also remain suspended after the majority of the nano-particles fall out deteriorating the thermal conductivity enhancement. However, there was no sign of sample color change or particle-base fluid reaction during the period of sample preparation and testing. Therefore, the nano-fluid samples used in this study were considered chemically stable.

sections.heading: 4. Summary and conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, commercially available Al2O3 nano-particles dispersed in DW, EG and EG/DW mixture at various concentrations were investigated as potential heat transfer fluids with enhanced thermal performance. Two-step process was developed and used for the sample preparation using the magnetic stirrer and horntype ultra-sonicator. The nano-fluid samples were characterized by the TEM imaging, particle surface charge (zeta potential), particle aggregate size, light absorbance and pH. Thermo-physical properties (thermal conductivity and viscosity) of the nano-fluid samples were measured. The particle sedimentation behavior was investigated. The following conclusions were made through the study:
1. The duration of ultra-sonication process was optimized for preferable particle aggregation size and thermal conductivity. It was also found that a prolonged ultra-sonication process caused sample contamination. 2. Al2O3 nano-particle aggregation is affected by the base fluid viscosity as well as the particle surface charge (zeta potential). 3. EG/DW mixture based nano-fluids showed overall higher thermal conductivity enhancement than DW and EG based nanofluids. Moderate aggregation is considered to attribute better enhancement, while either light or heavy aggregation could lower the enhancement. 4. The thermal conductivity enhancement over the base fluids increased with increase in particle loading.
5. The transient decline of the thermal conductivity enhancement is observed and correlated with the light absorbance. This decline is caused by the gravity-driven particle sedimentation and affected by the viscosity of the base fluid. 6. Nano-fluid viscosity augmentation over the base fluid is related to the particle aggregation. However, the extent of viscosity augmentation is not proportional to the extent of particle aggregation. 7. The impurity of the Al2O3 nano-powder was noticed from the pH change of the nano-fluid compared to the base fluid. This impurity may cause the nano-fluid thermal conductivity below the base fluid level after the majority of the nano-particles settle down.
